headline: Man United transfer news LIVE - Karim Adeyemi stance, Antoine Semenyo update, Jorthy Mokio claim
body: Hello and welcome to our Manchester United transfer news live blog on Thursday, November 20.

With the January transfer window fast approaching, United are at the centre of several rumours. Antoine Semenyo is currently the trending name ahead of the winter trading period with several Premier League teams keen to sign him from Bournemouth.
Karim Adeyemi of Borussia Dortmund is a different attacker to be linked with an Old Trafford switch, though the chances of that actually happening seem low.

Versatile Ajax star Jorthy Mokio is the latest midfield option to appear of interest to those at United with the almost certainly more expensive trio of Adam Wharton, Carlos Baleba and Elliot Anderson also wanted.
With all of that being said, MEN Sport has you covered with all of the latest transfer talk in our live blog below!
Kobbie Mainoo continues to be linked with a January loan move to Napoli.

The Manchester United midfielder wanted to depart the club temporarily on deadline day in search of more minutes, but was told he would not be leaving Old Trafford. He has since played just 93 minutes of Premier League football.

That has resulted in links to Napoli remaining with a mid-season switch now a seeming a real possibility, especially as he and Billy Gilmour share the same agent. CAA Stellar represent both midfielders and that could prove key in getting Mainoo to join.
Manchester United are firmly in the market to sign a new midfielder with a dream transfer option appearing to have now emerged.
According to The Daily Briefing. Ruben Neves is keen on a return to the Premier League when his contract at Al Hilal next summer.

It’s also claimed that contact is already being made with Premier League sides with a deal that would see him join United 'on'. Tottenham have also been credited with an interest in the former Wolves star.
If the 28-year-old does want to play in the Premier League next season, United could sign him on a free transfer, but there is likely to be serious competition if that scenario plays out.
Matheus Cunha could help Manchester United sign Wolves' Joao Gomes if he is the midfielder they actively pursue.
Cunha has spoken very highly of his fellow Brazilian. When he was asked who Gomes reminds him of, the forward made an exciting admission.

"Maybe Casemiro," he explained. "He is a bit older now, but I put Casemiro’s name there only to show where Joao Gomes could arrive. I think Joao has the possibility to arrive. He is very humble, and he works a lot. The good teams come like a gift when you do that."
Liverpool legend Jamie Carragher has instructed his former club to sign Antoine Semenyo from Bournemouth in the January transfer window.
Manchester United and Tottenham have been linked with a move for the Ghana international but Carragher has explained why Arne Slot desperately needs him.
Speaking on the Stick to Football podcast,he said: "I think they'll [Liverpool] have to recruit more physical players and maybe even in January.

"I’ve just seen the Semenyo [January release clause] come up and obviously he’s got the link with [sporting director] Richard Hughes. When you actually look at him as a player, lightening quick, big and powerful."
Manchester United are the latest club to be linked with a move for Ajax teenager Jorthy Mokio.
According to Sacha Tavolieri, there is transfer interest from Old Trafford in the 17-year-old, who can play in both midfield and defence, with Newcastle United and Eintracht Frankfurt also keen.

He has added that Mokio is currently uncertain about Ajax's long-term project and is thus yet to sign a new contract despite the club's wishes. That hesitation could result in one of the three teams linked taking advantage.
Manchester United are expected to be involved in the Antoine Semenyo transfer battle during the January transfer window.
The winger is likely to depart Bournemouth given the £65million release clause in his contract and with United, Tottenham and Liverpool all interested.

The latter appear to have the best chance of signing him with the Daily Mail (subscription required) describing Arne Slot's side as the frontrunners for his signature. It has been claimed however, that United are ones to watch in the battle to acquire his services.
Karim Adeyemi appears unlikely to join Manchester United from Borussia Dortmund.

Links to the Germany international had ramped up over the last few weeks but as things stand there is no active moves being made for him with transfer guru Fabrizio Romano revealing no approach or negotiations have started.

United could certainly look to bring in an attacker in the January transfer window especially if one more injury strikes with Benjamin Sesko currently out while Bryan Mbeumo and Amad will be at AFCON.
Hello and welcome back to our Manchester United transfer live blog!
For the latest updates on Karim Adeyemi, Antoine Semenyo, Jorthy Mokio, Adam Wharton, Elliot Anderson and Carlos Baleba!

Manchester United's Shea Lacey has long been touted as a star of the future - and it might not just be at club level. The 18-year-old has caught England's eye in recent weeks and months and again played a starring role on the international stage this week.
The United prospect came off the bench to score for England Under-20s in their 1-1 friendly draw with Japan on Friday night, having only made his debut at that level last month.
That outing came after the teenager was called up to train with the Under-21s - who beat Ireland 1-0 on Friday - where he received glowing praise from boss Lee Carsley.

Rasmus Hojlund's transfer value has increased yet again as he continues to enjoy his loan spell away from Manchester United. Hojlund left United to join Napoli on a season-long loan deal, which also includes an obligation to buy.

The reigning Serie A champions will have to pay United €44million (£38.8million) next summer provided certain conditions are met. The Reds have already received a €6million (£5.3million) loan fee from Napoli, which could mean the total fee for the transfer would reach €50million (£44.1million) if the permanent transfer is completed.

Hojlund left Old Trafford in the summer after scoring 26 goals across two seasons at United, and managed 10 across the entirety of the previous campaign. Since signing for Napoli, the Denmark international has four goals to his name across his first 10 appearances.

Manchester United are already being tipped to have a busy January transfer window, but Benjamin Sesko's injury could have the opposite effect. United have just over a month to go until they are allowed to go into the market for new signings once again.

Sesko was one of five new additions to the United squad in the summer, with Matheus Cunha, Bryan Mbeumo, Senne Lammens and Diego Leon all moving to Old Trafford. Despite making big moves in the transfer market a few months ago, United are still being linked with making further additions in the New Year.

However, the recent injury to Sesko could prompt a change in strategy from United. The Slovenia international suffered a knee injury during United's 2-2 draw with Tottenham Hotspur before the international break, with reports suggesting that he is expected to be sidelined for up to a month.
As a result, Ruben Amorim could be forced to turn to other members of his squad to fill the void left by Sesko's absence for the next few weeks.
Former Manchester United midfielder Gordon Strachan believes letting Marcus Rashford depart has proven to be the right decision by the club, as he has rediscovered his best form at Barcelona.

The 28-year-old winger joined the Spanish giants on a season-long loan in the summer, with the option to complete a permanent move to the Camp Nou. United included an option-to-buy clause in the deal worth around £28million.

Under manager Hansi Flick, the winger has scored six goals and provided nine assists in 16 appearances across all competitions. Strachan believes the move has worked out in favour of both player and club, having saved Ruben Amorim an extra headache in the dressing room.
Matheus Cunha labelled Ruben Amorim "a winner" when asked about the Manchester United boss while on international duty. The Reds signed Cunha for £62.5m from Wolves in the summer.

The early part of the campaign was particularly challenging for the club, increasing the pressure on Amorim. However, recent weeks have brought some relief and Cunha has expressed his admiration for the Portuguese coach and teammate Bryan Mbeumo.

Manchester United centre-back Lisandro Martinez has shown encouraging signs in training after being pictured with Joshua Zirkzee during the November international break. The Argentine has been out of action since sustaining a serious knee injury in February.

However, the 27-year-old has since returned to training at Carrington as he works his way back to full fitness. Reports suggest that Martinez was granted permission to train with Argentina during the international break to build match fitness.

It is currently unclear whether the former Ajax star will be fit enough to be included in United's squad for Monday night's clash against Everton, however. Reds boss Ruben Amorim is expected to provide an update during his pre-match press conference on Friday. And the latest signs are looking good for Martinez if Zirkzee's latest Instagram story post is anything to go by...

The January transfer window may be a notoriously difficult month for clubs to do business, but for Manchester United and other top teams it can present an opportunity. Players who are out of contract in the summer can speak to overseas clubs as early as January.

If you are club like United where there are a number of players out of contract at the end of the campaign, you need to decide what the plan is for them before January rolls around. If you don't, you risk losing players who you may wish to keep. With this in mind, MEN Sport has taken a look at five players United must make decisions on before the January window opens.

Furthermore, United will be in FA Cup third round action on the weekend of January 10, another fixture those players could be ruled out of. Ruben Amorim was asked about AFCON at a recent press conference and said: “We have time to suffer with that. We are going to struggle a little bit, but we already knew [that].

"It is going to be an opportunity because when I watch the training, there are players that should be playing, but it is hard with one game to take some players from the team because they are going well also, during training and the games. Other players are going to have the opportunity to help us, they are understanding the way we want to play. The change of characteristics are not going to change the idea or the momentum of the team, but let's use Amad and Bryan in these games and then we will see in January.”
Amorim will have the option of promoting young players in the absence of Mbeumo, Amad and Mazraoui, but which academy players have a chance of contributing to the first team?

Bruno Guimaraes has described Manchester United midfielder Casemiro as a "complete player". Casemiro has become an important player for club and country again, starting nine games in the Premier League and forcing his way back into Brazil's starting team under Carlo Ancelotti.

The 33-year-old has scored against Chelsea, Brighton and Nottingham Forest this season, and a conversation about whether he merits a contract extension has started among supporters. Casemiro has been representing Brazil during the international break. Newcastle captain Guimaraes sat down for a chat with Globo Esporte and he said he had been "inspired" by Casemiro.

When asked why he rates Casemiro so highly, Guimaraes said: "Experience, titles... he's a complete player. His career speaks for itself. In one of my first interviews with the national team, in 2020, when I arrived they asked if I was inspired by anyone in midfield, and I said his name, Casemiro.

Casemiro has easily been one of Manchester United's best players this season. The 33-year-old impressed in the Europa League last term but in the Premier League, where the pace is so fast, he faltered. And yet, this season he has looked a different player in the English top flight.

He has anchored the midfield and given Bruno Fernandes the freedom to push forward. However, he has also been a threat in the opposition box. Only Bryan Mbeumo has scored more than Casemiro for United this season, but with his contract expiring next summer, the Reds have a decision to make.

United could still extend his stay by a further year. It is believed the Reds would be happy to extend his contract, but only if he was willing to agree to a pay cut. If that agreement cannot be reached, United will lose their defensive midfielder and suddenly the search for his replacement becomes a priority. So far, the likes of Crystal Palace's Adam Wharton and Brighton's Carlos Baleba have been mentioned as options to replace Casemiro.

Joachim Andersen was visibly upset during a live TV interview after Denmark's guaranteed World Cup spot was dramatically taken by Scotland, with Scott McTominay's overhead kick leaving him in complete shock. Late goals from Kieran Tierney and Kenny Maclean secured the win for Scotland, despite Denmark twice equalising.

Former Manchester United star McTominay eased the tension at Hampden Park just three minutes into the game when he instinctively responded to a Ben Gannon Doak cross with an audacious overhead kick. Denmark later equalised through Reds loanee Rasmus Hojlund, whose penalty followed a foul by Andy Robertson, before Lawrence Shankland put the hosts back in the lead.

Rasmus Kristensen was shown a red card 15 minutes prior, but Denmark rallied once more with Patrick Dorgu netting a loose ball to level the score again. However, Steve Clarke's team ultimately triumphed when Kieran Tierney scored from distance in stoppage time, and Kenny McLean stylishly confirmed their place at next summer's tournament by lobbing Kasper Schmeichel from inside his own half.

Mason Greenwood's decision to snub a call-up to the Jamaica national team has been all but justified, after the Reggae Boyz missed out on automatic qualification for the World Cup.
Steve McClaren had hoped that former Manchester United forward Greenwood would represent Jamaica after it was announced that he had filed papers to request a switch in his international allegiance.

Reports last week, however, emerged that Greenwood, 24, is instead 'obsessed' with representing England again, more than five years since he made his Three Lions debut against Iceland. Although England head coach Thomas Tuchel has made it clear he is not in his thinking, Greenwood is still determined to return to international football with the Three Lions.

Manchester United approached Chelsea to enquire about the availability of Romeo Lavia in the summer transfer window, but at no point did higher-ups at Stamford Bridge put the 21-year-old midfielder on the table.
Meanwhile, the Blues pushed to sign Alejandro Garnacho from United, and Enzo Maresca eventually secured his signature at the end of August as part of a deal worth just £40m.
Manchester United have been issued with a stark reminder of what could have been at Old Trafford with Rasmus Hojlund and Scott McTominay on target in Scotland's thrilling win over Denmark last night.
The latter scored a stunning overhead kick to put Scotland in front, but it was Hojlund that cancelled it out from the penalty spot.

United star Patrick Dorgu was also on target to put Denmark on the brink of qualification for the World Cup, however late goals from Kieran Tierney and Kenny Maclean means Scotland have sealed a guaranteed spot at next summer's tournament.

The Napoli duo have been in impressive goal-scoring form since departing United with that continuing on international duty. In the last two-week domestic pause, Hojlund scored three goals while McTominay grabbed one assist.
Manchester United boss Ruben Amorim has received a welcome fitness boost in attack after losing Benjamin Sesko to injury.

The summer signing suffered a knee issue before the international break and is expected to miss the next few weeks at least. Bryan Mbeumo will also be unavailable for a similar period which makes Matheus Cunha that much more important.

He has already suffered an injury this season but any worries over him returning from Brazil with an issue or fatigue have been eased. That is because he played just 45 minutes of their friendly against Tunisia after featuring for 65 minutes against Senegal this past weekend.
Manchester United are still keeping tabs on Adam Wharton despite fresh links to Carlos Baleba, Elliot Anderson and Joao Gomes.

The Crystal Palace midfielder has continued his superb form into the new campaign which has prompted fresh links. Wharton himself recently responded to United rumours directly with those behind-the-scenes at Old Trafford forced into a summer plan.

According to ESPN, United will not make a move for a central midfielder in the winter window with the likes of Anderson and Wharton almost certainly not for sale. Gomes was an option given Wolves' struggles but that switch now seems off the table from both sides.
Manchester United have already been turned down by Antoine Semenyo as a number of Premier League clubs circle the Bournemouth star.
It has been widely reported there is a £65mllion release clause in his new contract that can be activated in the January transfer window.

Liverpool, Arsenal and Tottenham have all been linked with Semenyo in recent months with the latter also rejected by Semenyo with the Telegraph claiming that Ruben Amorim's side and Spurs saw £50million moves turned down by Semenyo, before he agreed fresh terms at Bournemouth.
Manchester United will likely struggle to sign Joao Gomes if they decide to make a move for the Wolves midfielder in the January transfer window.
Ruben Amorim's side have been monitoring the Brazil international over the last few months with a £44million price tag mooted.

However, folowing the appointment of Rob Edwards as the club's new head coach, it has been claimed there is gentleman's agreement in place not to sell the club's best players in January to give them the best possible chance of staying in the Premier League.

Manchester United are reportedly setting their sights on Wolves midfielder Joao Gomes as a potential January acquisition, in a deal that could save them £60million compared to signing Carlos Baleba.
The Reds have been linked with the Brighton and Hove Albion star, but it's suggested that the Seagulls would demand around £104million (€120m) for the Cameroon international.
Portuguese media outlet Record reports that Gomes is open to a move to Old Trafford and could be signed for just £44m ahead of the January window.

Since Jason Wilcox took over as sporting director, United have prioritised signing players with Premier League experience, as demonstrated by the arrivals of Matheus Cunha and Bryan Mbeumo. The club have also shortlisted players such as on Elliot Anderson, Carlos Baleba, Joao Gomes and Adam Wharton, further evidence of their new mandate.

Semenyo was on United's radar this summer, with reports claiming that Amorim met him for a meal in London. The forward's stock has increased since then, sparking interest from Liverpool and Tottenham.

Forest are reportedly likely to demand a huge fee for Elliot Anderson amid interest from Manchester United, according to the Telegraph.
It is suggested that the 23-year-old midfielder, who is valued at at least £100m, has no release, buy-back or sell-on clauses in his current Forest deal.
The report also suggests there is no chance of a winter sale, however, Forest are braced for bids in the summer with Newcastle also interested.

headline: RAILSTON: Manchester United's exciting goalkeeper reveals his two targets - 'It would be a dream'
body: Manchester United loanee Radek Vitek wants to spend the full season with Bristol City and challenge for the No.1 goalkeeper position at Old Trafford when he returns to the club. Vitek spent last season on loan with Austrian club FC Blau-Weiß Linz. He started every league game except three due to injury, and his time playing in Europe was a resounding success.

The 22-year-old was sent to Bristol City on a season-long loan for 2025/2026. Vitek has made a great impression in the Championship and has been tipped to make an impact at United after his loan stint. Senne Lammens was signed for £18.2million from Royal Antwerp in the summer transfer window, but Vitek could potentially challenge Lammens for his starting position when he returns.

Speaking to BBC Radio Bristol, Vitek said: "At the moment, the main goal is probably to stay here the whole season and play as many matches as possible. Every game brings different challenges and that's how you get as a young keeper the most experience, because you can be third goalkeeper on the training pitch when you're at Manchester United or big clubs like that but it will never give you the experience from the field.

"The past three months it's another step forward for me from last year and there are players with more quality and different solutions in front of goal, so I need to make more quick decisions and be ready."

Almost every academy player who leaves on loan has a recall break clause that can be activated after six months, which gives United a chance to assess whether it's best for the youngster to stay at their temporary club. Vitek is expected to see out the full season at Bristol City, and he discussed his ambition to play at Old Trafford after his loan.

"That's my plan, but I will do my maximum for that and we will see," he said. "Let's take game by game and now I'm focussing to play for Bristol City and doing my best. One day it would be a dream to play for Manchester United, but I will take it game by game, and I know there's a big challenge in front of me, but I want to improve every week."

Vitek delivered a man-of-the-match performance in United's opening pre-season friendly against Rosenborg in 2024, but he didn't join this summer's tour of the United States because he was due to leave on loan
The goalkeeper signed a new United contract until 2028 before joining Bristol City on loan.

headline: Man United should repeat Bryan Mbeumo trick after £65m transfer green light
body: Manchester United's summer transfer window went well, but heading towards January the Reds know there is work to be done as their squad still feels light in certain areas. Even with the arrivals of Benjamin Sesko, Matheus Cunha and Bryan Mbeumo, the Reds still feel short in attack. Sesko's injury has shown that to be the case.

Should Sesko miss any upcoming games, United seem destined to play Cunha as the false nine with Mbeumo and one of Mason Mount or Amad behind him. But when Mbeumo and Amad leave for AFCON, United suddenly look very short. Ruben Amorim did hint after the Tottenham draw that he could delve into the January market, especially if Sesko's injury is serious.

Even if Sesko doesn't miss a game for United it must be clear to Amorim that another forward addition is needed. Fortunately, the green light has just been given to repeat a trick United used in the summer. The Reds targeted attackers who, as Jason Wilcox put it, can 'plug in and play'. Mbeumo in particular looks to be a very good piece of business as he settles into his new surroundings and continues to score goals.

There is clearly something to be said for signing players who have Premier League experience and so United should be on the lookout for any players at fellow Premier League clubs who could be on the move. According to The Athletic, Bournemouth's top scorer Antoine Semenyo has a release clause of just £65m this winter.

United would need to act quickly to activate it though as it is claimed to expire early in the January window. But, if they did want to make a move, why would United hesitate? Semenyo is a proven goalscorer at this level, with six in 11 for Bournemouth so far this season.

While he has been utilised as a winger this season, he has more than enough experience as a centre-forward to provide decent competition for Sesko at the top end of the pitch. The only issue is whether United would have the funds to activate his release clause. The obvious candidate if United were to sell before they can buy is Joshua Zirkzee.

It is hard to envisage a scenario where Zirkzee gets game time ahead of Sesko, or any of United's other attacking players for that matter. It is believed the striker is set to hand in a transfer request in January and any funds raised from his sale could help a swoop for Semenyo.

It is a deal that would make a lot of sense for United but there will be other teams wanting to snap him up. Liverpool and Tottenham are among the other clubs thought to be keen on him so the Reds would need to act quickly.

headline: RAILSTON: Manchester United's new appointment promises investment during first interview
body: During Cox's nine-year stint as academy boss he played a pivotal role in the United academy renaissance, secured top youth signings and oversaw an FA Youth Cup triumph in 2022. Torpey relocated to Manchester from Brentford. He was previously at Manchester City, where he spent nine-and-a-half years working in different positions alongside Jason Wilcox.

The 44-year-old has been spotted at academy fixtures alongside Wilcox, and he recently gave his first interview since his arrival from Brentford in a lengthy conversation with club media. Torpey said: “I know this is Manchester United, we've done amazing things in youth, but I feel it's my duty now to continue that. You know, I've heard my predecessor, Nick [Cox], talk about carrying on the baton, and I believe in that.

“I've been very fortunate to have the tours around Old Trafford and Littleton Road and The Cliff and realise the heritage, you know, and I got to thank [club historian] Jason Leach for taking me around and showing me the ropes on that. “What it made me realise was this club's been built on innovation and a real belief in youth and a bravery to implement youth and look after the club really by utilising the youth that we had and that privilege that I feel I've got now.

“That pressure just comes with that sustainability of that and creating young players that are ready for the first team. You know, we don't want it to be a token gesture, that we have players in our first team because we want to keep a tradition going. We want to have players that are ready, that can make an impact, that can make our first team better, and most importantly, our fans can be proud of.

“You know, I genuinely believe that. I've been very fortunate now to watch players I've worked with over the years go on and represent their country, represent the club, win the best trophies. And there's no greater feeling than one of your own stepping out.”

Torpey was asked how the academy would change under his leadership and said: “It's still early days for me, but ultimately we've got to sustain everything that's happened in the past and sustain the high level of delivery and development of our young players.

"And this is an institution. This is world renowned. It's almost that privilege and that pinch yourself moment to be here, sat here talking about this. “But at the same time, we've got to take all these things from the historic upbringing and the way that Manchester United is and what it represents, take all those amazing things, enhance them further if we can, and do more of them in terms of our welcoming nature for the young players.

"But also looking at things that are going to make us even better, you know, and how can we make them better? It goes back to that critical thinking again and asking the right questions and developing certain areas.
“The most important thing is we've got a first-team environment right now that is world class. And we've got to do the same. It's very good where we are right now.

"And it's served us well, but we've also got to make something that is world class, innovative and gives us the spaces and the technology that's going to allow us to do an even better job in the modern era."
He continued: “Then just looking at our processes from a development point of view and trying to take all that experience that we talked about before, those years of different places.

“The innovation for us right now is in facilities, first and foremost. But we've got to understand what it is we want to do in the future, why we want to do it. We've got some fantastic staff. We've got to make sure that they're not operating with their hands tied behind their backs in the modern development landscape. “So that's important for us now, to look at that, to evaluate and then execute on a fantastic new facility that's going to help us sustain our work for the long term and for the next 10, 15, 20 years’ worth of youth development at this football club. Hopefully that will help us support more players into the Manchester United first team.”

Last month, United announced the academy building at Carrington will be redeveloped. United unveiled a £50million makeover to the main building in August and announced plans to bring academy facilities in line with the 'leading standards' they have for the first team.

There will be upheaval while the academy building is redeveloped, meaning the Under-21s and Under-18s will use the modular building, a two-storey block behind the main building. The women's team used the same set-up during the £10m redevelopment of their facilities at Carrington.

headline: Cristiano Ronaldo net worth can surpass David Beckham and Lionel Messi after Donald Trump visit
body: Cristiano Ronaldo could be poised to boost his earnings by an additional $100m (£76.5m) in the United States following his appearance at the White House.

The Portuguese superstar has built an extraordinary reputation through a remarkable footballing journey spanning Sporting CP, Manchester United, Real Madrid, Juventus and most recently, Al-Nassr. Yet according to Professor Rob Wilson, Director of Executive Education at University Campus of Football Business, the 40-year-old's activities away from the pitch may enable him to develop a more substantial brand than the likes of David Beckham and long-standing rival, Lionel Messi.

Speaking to Vegas Insider after Ronaldo was seen at the White House State Banquet, the specialist said: "Ronaldo already operates as a billion-dollar global asset. But that White House moment will add political relevance and some hugely important US visibility which are powerful brand signals.

"When Donald Trump frames Ronaldo as a family favourite of his son, it humanises his image and broadens sponsor appeal. The earned media impact from such exposure would likely sit in the mid eight-figure range, with a small uplift to endorsement pricing in a portfolio already producing well over $60m (£45.9m) a year.
"We can expect CR7 to press on toward $100m (£76.5m) endorsements in the US as a result of his invitation and appearance at the banquet."

Professor Wilson also drew comparisons between Ronaldo's American presence and Messi, who has taken comparable measures recently to feature alongside the US president. He continued: "Messi's shift into high-level business forums, such as his appearance at the America Business Forum alongside Donald Trump, helps reframe him from elite athlete to national economic ambassador.

"Messi's brand is already approaching $1bn (£765m) in value with demonstrable commercial impact as shown by Inter Miami's revenue doubling and valuation jumping past $1bn (£765m) itself. His presence signals reliability to investors and governments. It positions him for equity stakes, long-term partnerships and sovereign-level ventures rather than conventional sponsorships.

"Beckham still sets the standard for turning fame into a lifestyle empire, backed by a half-billion-pound image rights business and a stake in a billion-dollar club. But Messi and Ronaldo now sit on larger global platforms with bigger fan ecosystems and deeper earning power.

"Each has the scale to become a long-term institutional brand, Ronaldo as a luxury fitness, Gulf-backed platform with Messi acting as a soft-power bridge across the Americas and the global football economy. Both have the potential to surpass Beckham's long-term commercial footprint with carefully curated activations and appearances."

This year, Ronaldo made history by becoming the first active footballer to reach billionaire status. This is in part due to his lucrative contract with Al-Nassr in the Saudi Pro League, which is reportedly worth over $400m (£306m).
Currently, it's estimated that Ronaldo's net worth stands at around $1.4billion (£1bn).

To put this into perspective, Ronaldo's wealth far surpasses that of David and Victoria Beckham, who have a combined net worth of £500m, as well as Lionel Messi, whose fortune is reported to be around $850m (£650m).

headline: Ex-Man United star makes exciting Chido Obi claim as Benjamin Sesko injury wait continues
body: Manchester United have been urged to give minutes to Chido Obi while Benjamin Sesko is ruled out through injury. Sesko is currently recovering from a knee injury that he suffered before the international break.

The Slovenia international picked up the injury during United's 2-2 draw with Tottenham Hotspur earlier this month. Reports this week have claimed that Sesko is expected to be on the sidelines for up to a month.

Sesko has scored two goals for United since his £74million move from RB Leipzig during the summer transfer window. Ruben Amorim will now be tasked with managing the United squad for the next few weeks with Sesko on the sidelines, which will include Premier League matches against Everton, Crystal Palace and West Ham.

It remains to be seen what Amorim will have planned to cope with Sesko's absence, and former United striker Dwight Yorke believes that Obi should be given an opportunity. Yorke, who scored 66 goals during his time at Old Trafford, has argued why Amorim should turn to United's academy starlets during Sesko's time on the sidelines.
“I think Amorim has got to invest in the young players and bring some fresh talent through to give a little bit of a chance if Sesko is out injured,” Yorke said in an interview with Snabbare.

“If you're going to bring in a makeshift option as cover, we’ve seen United do that in the past and it hasn't worked. It's too big of a club for bringing in a player that’s not the right fit to improve the team. I’d understand if they were firing on all cylinders to get someone else in there but when things are not going so great, it’s a difficult fit.

“If United are going to go and sign someone else, I think they have to go out there like Liverpool and bring in someone who would have a really big presence at the football club. Otherwise, the under-23s are there for a reason.”
Yorke went on to argue why Obi deserves an opportunity for the United first team over the next few weeks.
“What about Chido Obi? I know the first-team squads are big but you’ve got to get these young players around the team for when situations like this happen," said Yorke.

"When I was at United, the youngsters could train with us and then we’d let them play to get game time and train with us more. It’s so that when they come, they are already up to speed. That’s something I would look at.
“I would like to see Obi put in if Sesko is out. If you're good enough to be at United, you've got to give them a chance.
"History has shown that this is a club where young players get that chance to stand in and step up and we’ve seen that time and time again.

“If they're going down the road of just trying to bring in somebody who's just okay, United will find themselves going back down the other way again, and I wouldn't go down that road. We’ve seen where that goes.”

headline: Kobbie Mainoo told which club has "best conditions" as transfer decision looms
body: Former Arsenal midfielder Stefan Schwarz reckons the Emirates would prove an ideal destination for Kobbie Mainoo should the England international opt to depart Manchester United. Mainoo emerged as a breakthrough star for United throughout the 2023/24 campaign. Having progressed through the academy ranks, the Reds appeared to have nurtured another triumphant homegrown prospect.
Despite such an encouraging beginning to his professional journey, the 20-year-old indicated his wish to exit Old Trafford during the summer window, with his squad status remaining uncertain.

United boss Ruben Amorim has preferred a two-man midfield setup this term, with Casemiro and Bruno Fernandes steering the side. This has resulted in Mainoo accumulating just 138 minutes of action in the current season.

Chelsea were reportedly interested in the promising midfielder during the summer transfer window, though Arsenal have subsequently surfaced as a prospective future destination. Schwarz reckons such a switch could prove advantageous for Mainoo.

He told Hajper: "Kobbie Mainoo's links to Arsenal? Arsenal have the best conditions for young players. And they have a manager in Mikel Arteta that is not afraid to give responsibility to them and give them opportunities when he feels they are ready. It's just about preparing them in the best way and that's what Arsenal have done very well the last couple of years."

Arteta is often lauded for his knack of promoting young academy players to the first team. Under Arteta's guidance, Bukayo Saka has blossomed into a star player for the Gunners, with the Spanish manager honing Saka's wing role and structuring the attack around him.
One of Mainoo's standout attributes is his composed and mature presence in midfield. Regrettably, it seems the youngster has lost much of the responsibility once bestowed upon him by Erik ten Hag.

Amorim appears to favour a 'safer' pairing with seasoned players Casemiro and Fernandes. However, should Mainoo transfer to Arsenal this winter, it's likely that Arteta would restore that level of responsibility to the 20-year-old.
His performances at United secured him a place in Gareth Southgate's England squad. The England manager showed enough faith in Mainoo to start him in the 2024 Euros final against Spain.
Mainoo's contract with United runs until 2027. The midfielder is reportedly open to a loan move this season and has currently put new contract discussions on hold.

headline: Rasmus Hojlund value increases despite Man United transfer nightmare as reality clear
body: Rasmus Hojlund's transfer value has increased yet again as he continues to enjoy his loan spell away from Manchester United. Hojlund left United to join Napoli on a season-long loan deal, which also includes an obligation to buy.

The reigning Serie A champions will have to pay United €44million (£38.8million) next summer provided certain conditions are met. The Reds have already received a €6million (£5.3million) loan fee from Napoli, which could mean the total fee for the transfer would reach €50million (£44.1million) if the permanent transfer is completed.

Hojlund left Old Trafford in the summer after scoring 26 goals across two seasons at United, and managed 10 across the entirety of the previous campaign. Since signing for Napoli, the Denmark international has four goals to his name across his first 10 appearances.

Only time will tell if Hojlund will complete a permanent move to Napoli next summer or return to United. With the striker enjoying his time in Italy, his market value appears to have increased over the last few months.
The CIES Football Observatory have crunched the numbers and put Hojlund's current market value at between €79million (£69.7m) and €92million (£81.1m).
This marks quite a significant increase in Hojlund's value since the end of last season.
Back in June, the same website listed the striker's value on the transfer market as between €59million (£52m) and €76million (£67m).
Napoli are yet to confirm that they will sign Hojlund on a permanent deal next summer, so it's still unclear if all of the conditions of the loan move have been met.
The striker will still have the chance to compete for the Serie A title and the Champions League throughout the season.
There have even been rumours that United could have the option of recalling Hojlund when the January transfer window opens, in the aftermath of Benjamin Sesko's knee injury.
The Slovenian international suffered the injury before the international break, with further updates since claiming that the striker will be on the sidelines for up to a month.
At the time of the injury, there were fears that Sesko could be ruled out for an even longer spell.

This led to rumours about whether or not United could recall Hojlund in January, but this will not be the case due to there being no such clause included in the transfer, which was agreed earlier this year.

headline: Man United know the one thing they can't do in Marcus Rashford transfer plan
body: Manchester United will find it difficult not to look on enviously at Barcelona this season considering how well Marcus Rashford has done for them.
The loan spell to Catalonia was the last throw of the dice for Rashford. His bridges were burnt with Ruben Amorim and, for all involved, the best thing to do was to let him leave.
Rashford wanted Barca in January but an approach was not deemed viable by the La Liga giants. Fortunately for the United academy graduate, they returned in the summer and the deal was done.

He joined the Camp Nou club on a season-long loan with the option to purchase him in the summer. If all goes according to plan for United, Rashford will impress, Barca will trigger that option and the winger's time in Spain continues.

Six goals and nine assists in 16 appearances suggests Barca will want to keep Rashford. Whether they have the finances to do it is another issue. Barca can sign the England international for £28m in the summer but the financial pressures Barcelona face are well documented.
No matter how well Rashford does at Barca or for England, he will not have a place to come back to at Old Trafford. Amorim has made his mind up and therefore the task would be to find him a new club.
Kitbag has slashed the price of Man United kits and merch with up to 50% off select items.

With that in mind, United know what they can't do. Sell Rashford to a Premier League rival. In Spain, El Nacional has reported that Chelsea and Tottenham Hotspur have both made early contact with Rashford's agent to try and persuade him to move to the Premier League. United can't let that happen.

If he was to impress in the Premier League, suddenly Rashford becomes a more prominent issue for the United head coach. So ideally United must find a way of making things work with Barca. The alternative of him returning to England with Chelsea or Spurs is not worth thinking about.
United can only hope that if it comes to it, Rashford still does not fancy a move down to London...

headline: RAILSTON: How Manchester United's 18 loanees are doing this season - Rashford, Onana and Collyer
body: Manchester United sent plenty of players out on loan in the summer transfer window.
Marcus Rashford and Andre Onana were among the highest-profile loan exits from the club, while Rasmus Hojlund and Jadon Sancho completed moves to Napoli and Aston Villa respectively.

There were several players from the academy sent on loan to gain experience. Some of those youngsters are excelling, while others have not made the impact they might have hoped. United loaned 18 players in total - and here is how they are faring this season.

Sheffield Wednesday have been hit with a 12-point deduction due to their ownership situation, but they were able to promise regular game time to Amass, who has made 11 starts. The youngster scored his first senior goal against Southampton and United are delighted with his stint so far.

Collyer was limited to seven substitute appearances after his arrival. He broke into the starting team against Millwall last month and retained his role in the next game, but he picked up a muscle injury.

Ennis spent the second half of last season with promotion-winning Doncaster Rovers. The youngster joined Fleetwood on a season-long deal for this campaign and he has started eight league games. Has contributed two goals and an assist during his positive loan spell in League Two.

Gore picked up an injury shortly after signing for Rotherham last January, but he made a strong impression in the time he was available, so he was re-signed for this season. Gore has been crucial for Rotherham in midfield. Has started in 15 games in League One and has been one of their best players.

Onana has received praise in the Turkish media since his move to Trabzonspor, who have lost just once in the league from a possible eight games since he signed. The 29-year-old has recorded three clean sheets and helped Trabzonspor to third in the table.

After missing the opening two games of the League Two campaign due to a minor injury, Harrison started the next four games for Shrewsbury Town before reporting for England Under-20 duty in September. In his absence, another young goalkeeper came into the side and has earned first-choice status over Harrison.
Hugill started the first two games of the season for Barnet in League Two, but he picked up an injury and has been absent since.

Defender Aljofree started the first eight games of the campaign and notched a goal but he has lost his starting role over the last few weeks. The 20-year-old was not in the squad for Notts County played Harrogate Town last weekend.

Solihull Moors are midtable in the National League. Jackson started in their first two games of the season, but he has struggled to make the XI since. The centre-back has been absent from their last five matchday squads.

Hojlund made an excellent first impression in Naples, scoring twice against Sporting Lisbon in the Champions League shortly after his arrival, but he has scored just four goals in total. Hojlund has copped some flak from the Italian media for his recent performances. Napoli won Serie A last season but sit fourth.
Kana-Biyik recently scored his first senior goal. He salvaged a point for Lausanne in a local derby and was called up to France's Under-20 squad for the November international break.
Moorhouse has made 15 appearances for League One side Leyton Orient, but just four of those have been league starts. The youngster has shown glimpses of quality from the bench.

Dave Hughes, who coached Ogunneye in United's academy, has just departed Newport County. That might impact Ogunneye's role in the squad, but the youngster has made 13 league starts in League Two so far and gained valuable experience, albeit in a struggling dressing room.

Barcelona seemed a great fit for Rashford to rediscover his form. The United academy graduate has contributed six goals and nine assists in 16 appearances this season, and has looked back to his best.

Rashford has been revitalised by leaving on loan - but Sancho continues to be in a slump. The winger has not started for Aston Villa in the Premier League and has failed to record a goal or an assist.

Vitek has started every league game for Bristol City in the Championship, keeping five clean sheets. The 22-year-old has made some great saves. Bristol City manager Gerhard Struber recently said of Vitek to the Bristol Post: “He’s young, and he looks like an outstanding, experienced Championship goalkeeper.”

Wheatley needed to leave on loan after outgrowing academy football. The young striker has made 13 starts in League Two for Northampton and has found the back of the net twice, as well as recording two assists.

Williams is performing well north of the border. Has contributed a goal and three assists in nine appearances in the Scottish top-flight for Falkirk, who are exceeding expectations by sitting fifth in the table.

headline: Man United manager didn't respect me so I had to leave - now I'm on the brink of World Cup history
body: Zidane Iqbal is used to making history.

The midfielder became the first British-born South Asian to represent Manchester United and the first to play in the Champions League. Iqbal came off the bench against Young Boys in December 2021 and at that stage in his career it looked only a matter of time until he was handed more regular opportunities.

Chances may not have materialised at Old Trafford but Iqbal and his Iraq team-mates have a significant one tonight. A win against the United Arab Emirates in the home leg of their World Cup qualifying play-off will keep alive the dream of qualifying for the tournament next summer.

Iqbal, who was the first Iraqi to play for United, came off the bench in last week's first leg, which ended 1-1 and leaves Iraq as marginal favourites to progress. Should they prevail they will enter a six team inter-continental play-off in March. Their world ranking is likely to see them go straight into one of the two finals and thus one win away from the World Cup.

For Iraq that would be a first appearance since their sole qualification in 1986. For Iqbal it would be the latest piece of history and perhaps vindication for opting to leave United and move to Utrecht in the Netherlands.
The tipping point for the now 22-year-old was a lack of opportunities and a seeming lack of trust from then manager Erik ten Hag in granting him a first team chance during the 2022-23 campaign.

"I thought I would get a chance and unfortunately I didn’t," said Iqbal in an interview last summer. "I just wanted 10 minutes off a bench to show myself and it really frustrated me that the gaffer didn’t seem to rate me enough to give me a chance to show if I could sink or swim.

"I spoke to my dad and agent and said: 'I can't do this for another year'. From the outside, it looked amazing to all my friends because I was training and travelling with United’s first team. For me, it was mentally tough because I was just training and not allowed to play with the Under-23s. I thought to myself, 'I'm just like a number'.

"I was supposed to start a cup game against Charlton. I was in all the shapes and patterns in pre-match training. I was starting as a 10 and Lisandro Martinez came up to me and said: 'Now's your chance'. He talked to me and said, 'all of us are supporting you. Just show yourself, you're a good player. We're going to fight for you, make sure you're ready to fight'. It motivated me and it was nice from him, an aggressive leader in the team, a big player. I got tickets for family and friends to see me. Finally, my chance.

"Then I got to the stadium, looked at the whiteboard and didn't see my name. I was gutted. Then I thought I'd come off the bench. Nothing. That was the turning point for me. I didn't feel the manager respected me enough to play me."

Iqbal turned down the chance to play at the Under-19 World Cup in April 2023 after Ten Hag told him he wanted to retain him as part of the United senior squad, but no club minutes followed and that summer he left for the Netherlands for a fee in the region of £1million.

Injury has hampered his opportunity for regular minutes in Holland but he is closing in on 50 senior opportunities for the club and is a regular for the national team, scoring a crucial goal in a victory over Indonesia earlier this season. He'd love another against the UAE this afternoon (4pm), it would be the latest chapter of a history-making career.

headline: Man United star Mason Mount reaches out to family after horror crash and critical injury
body: Mason Mount has shown support for the family of a big Manchester United fan in Bolton who continues to fight for his life after being struck by a car. Mount has sent a video message to Lewis Rimmer's wife, Sarah, and two daughters, Amelia and Maddison, in the aftermath of a Range Rover hitting him and causing 'life-changing' injuries.

He remains 'critically ill' in hospital after being put in an induced coma, his close friend Andy Tonge has told the MEN. Tonge described the message as 'lovely' for the family. The Bolton News quotes him as saying: "They're big Manchester United supporters, so this was lovely to receive, what a guy."

Mount is said to have shared his condolences and expressed his sorrow at hearing what happened to Rimmer. He also relayed that "everyone at Manchester United is thinking of them and sending all their love." A fundraiser set up by friends to raise money for the family has received over £100,000 in donations.

Tonge has said: "The incident seems to have really struck a chord with people. It happened during half term, and it’s shocked so many because it could so easily have been a child who might not have been as strong as Lewis is proving to be.
"Many feel that Lewis’ strength and fight over the last few weeks is nothing short of remarkable.
"The fact that it took place at a local supermarket, used by so many of us, has created an even stronger sense of, 'This could have happened to anyone of us.'"

Tonge added: "Lewis, unfortunately, is still critically ill and remains in an induced coma, three weeks on. Sarah and the family have been by his side every single day, and the fundraiser has genuinely lifted them.
"Knowing that so many people care and want to support them has made a real difference.
"When the time comes to make necessary changes to their home and daily life, they’ll be able to focus on Lewis without the added pressure of financial worries."

headline: Two Manchester United players have what it takes to recover from setbacks
body: Modern football is often a reflection of the world surrounding it.

When the older generations were watching the sport in the 1960s and 1970s, discussions surrounding the mental stability of a player or the squad was rarely aired. However, as the world became more aware of the challenges of mental health, football has accepted it and now each Premier League club takes into account the psychological fortitude of a player during every aspect of their career - all the way from scouting to the day they depart.
Manchester United are no exception and within their current squad there are two players who are facing mental challenges which shall be putting them to the test. First, is Lisandro Martinez.

Little more than a year after suffering a severe foot injury, the Argentine damaged his ACL and has been sidelined since February. He is now back with the United camp as he continues his recovery and his return to the pitch is expected before the festive period.

But managing to navigate past the mental barrier of returning to professional football will be the crucial step in Martinez's recovery. Specialist in psychology at Manchester Metropolitan University Dr Martin Turner, who has worked with The FA and Scarlets Rugby, believes the 27-year-old could come back a stronger athlete.
"I imagine he [Martinez] will be worrying that it [his injury] would happen again," Dr Turner told MEN Sport. "That is just sensible. That is just the reality.

"What you wouldn’t want a player like that to do is delude themselves that this will never happen again and everything is always going to be hunky-dory because sport is so unpredictable, and there is so much uncertainty that you can never really predict what is going to happen.

"But having gone through two quite difficult injuries, he will have learnt quite a lot and his personality and character would have had some shifts. From my experience of working with athletes who have especially had these back-to-back injuries and even sometimes surgeries, they do develop a shift in their personality.

"I wouldn’t say it is necessarily more resilience, but there is clarity there of what this means to them. They suddenly have a gratitude and thinking of: ‘Well, this could go away at any minute, so I am going to apply myself doubly compared to what I was doing before. I am going to really take care of this and do all the right things.'"

"You can’t put it to one side and say that is done now because there will be monitoring that takes place after training and after performances around that injury and around recovery to make sure that everything is going well.
"There will be physical limitations because it will have been a long time since they have played to the intensity of a proper game.

"So it is not just a case of putting it to the back of your mind but about trusting the medical professionals you are working with to know that they would not let you step on this pitch, if you wasn’t physically right. Players have to take confidence from that and trust the people they are working with and then they can trust their bodies."

Martinez's teammate Bryan Mbeumo is currently negotiating a different type of mental challenge heading out of the international break. Last week, Cameroon lost to DR Congo in World Cup qualifying meaning Mbeumo's national team will not be competing in the USA, Mexico and Canada next summer.

Missing out on the World Cup, arguably the pinnacle of football, will have been a bitter blow for Mbeumo to take but Dr Turner believes that United do not have to fear the forward's confidence dropping upon his return to England.

"I am not sure they would have to do, or do anything special there," he explained. "Experienced players are able to lift themselves, really, and move on quite quickly. One of the good things about football in particular is how quickly things move from game-to-game.

"Say you play badly and then you play well in the next game, it is sort of completely forgotten. Things move on so quickly so he would be expected to come back and hit the ground running and get his club mentality on.

"I think the direction of football, particularly in this country, is more of a club mentality and it is realised that is your bread and butter. I wouldn’t foresee any issues there and I wouldn’t expect staff to do anything in particular for that player.
"I might be wrong and I have no idea what is going on behind the scenes, but from my experience of being in environments like that, it would be an expectation to get back on your feet and go again.

"The more that you make a big deal of something that has happened or bring it into the room, the more that is going to affect other players so you have got to get him back moving, playing and within the mentality of the squad."

headline: Why phone call with Man United star can give Ruben Amorim boost he needs
body: Earlier this month, Manchester United fans were left scratching their heads as one of their best players this season was snubbed again.

Luke Shaw endured a tough start to the season, following on from a campaign ruined by injuries. The 2024/25 season did not go according to plan for anyone in red, but Shaw in particular was being doubted after another season spent mainly on the sidelines.
However, full credit must go to Shaw for the manner in which he has bounced back.

Following the disaster at Manchester City, Shaw has been dependable for the Reds this campaign in a back three. He had to deal with plenty of criticism following that derby day defeat - notably from Roy Keane - and after addressing it, he set about making amends.

Ever since that game, Shaw has got better and better for United and you can see him settling into his new role on the left side of defence. That's why it was surprising when England head coach Thomas Tuchel overlooked him for the final World Cup qualifiers this month.

While being overlooked for selection will have been a blow to Shaw, Ruben Amorim will have taken the positives from the decision. He admitted himself, from a selfish perspective, he wanted all his players to be training and recovering at United during the international break. But he would still be delighted to see Shaw competing with England.

"For me, I want him to go to the national team, but I also want Luke Shaw to train with me, recover with me, and be prepared for my game, so I'm a little bit selfish on that, so if he's not going to the national team, for me it's fine, because I can control better what he's doing," Amorim said earlier this season.

While missing out on the November camp was a big blow for Shaw, Tuchel has admitted it is not necessarily the end of his World Cup dream. "First of all, it's my job now to make contact with everyone," the England head coach said at the end of the Three Lions' final international break this year.

"Players like Trent [Alexander-Arnold], players that are on our long list, 55, 60 players, to reach out to them, be in touch with them, explain to them why they were not here. Explain to them what they have to do, where they can improve.
"Can they even do something or is it just a choice, so this is my job in the next weeks and months."
Shaw and Harry Maguire will be on Tuchel's list of 55-60 players who he is in contact with to discuss their spots in the England squad.
That phone call should work to United's benefit. Shaw will know exactly what he needs to do over the next few months to put himself in contention and that can only help United.
Shaw will be eager to show Tuchel that he was wrong to overlook him. The best way to do that will be to impress for Amorim and the Reds.

headline: Matthijs de Ligt makes true feelings on biggest Ruben Amorim criticism at Man United clear
body: Manchester United centre-back Matthijs de Ligt has admitted he is finding the five-at-the-back system under Ruben Amorim easier as time progresses.

Amorim has been heavily criticised for his decision to stick with the five-at-the-back defence, with three centre-backs playing alongside two wing-backs. Some argued the Portuguese head coach needed to be pragmatic and revert to a traditional four-at-the-back system in order to secure results.

Prior to the Burnley victory and with scrutiny mounting, the United boss told reporters: "Guys, if I feel that it's best to change... I played all my life in the 4-4-2, 4-3-3. The only system that I didn't play one minute: 3-4-3.

"I just have one idea that we need to be so good in this way of playing, then we are going to adapt. It's like some coaches have a mentality that I'm going to put this system, and then I'm going to change.
"What I'm thinking is that we have one system that is going to adapt to different systems, and then when everyone is doing this with his eyes shut, I'm going to change a lot of things."
United are on a five-game unbeaten run and sit a point outside the top four. Integral to this recent form has been De Ligt, who has started every Premier League match for Amorim this season.

On Monday night, he played the full 90 minutes alongside Liverpool's Virgil van Dijk in a back four as the Netherlands beat Lithuania in their final World Cup qualifier to top their group. After the game, De Ligt was quizzed on his preference and the 26-year-old insisted that he does not have one.
"No, I don't really have a preference," he told Flashscore. "We play with a five-man defence at Manchester United, but on paper, we defend with four.
"It didn't feel awkward today; it felt the same as always. I can play in both systems. I'm more experienced with a five-man defence now; the more experience you have, the easier it gets."
In the last match before the November international break, you could see De Ligt's point in practice. United would often drop to a back four with Luke Shaw moving into central midfield.

The Netherlands have now qualified for the World Cup and De Ligt expressed his delight post-match to have made his first start for his country since last November. "Whether it's a comeback? Yeah, a bit," he admitted.
"I wasn't here last time, I haven't started for a long time, so I'm delighted with today. The season is going well so far.
"I'm not sure if you call it a comeback season, but I'm feeling well, and it's going better with the club, and now I'm rewarded with a start, so that's great."
"It's [the World Cup] still far away," De Ligt added. "It'll be about being fit a lot, that's the most important thing to everyone."

headline: Senne Lammens 'can become the best in the world' - Manchester United have a new star
body: Senne Lammens wore a polo shirt and a navy sweatshirt when he visited Old Trafford after signing for Manchester United. The young goalkeeper looked as though he could be joining United to work in their HR department.
The same observation was made when Lammens reported for international duty with Belgium last week - the 23-year-old was dressed in a beige collared jacket, a khaki t-shirt and chinos.

"By accident, I saw an article saying he was wearing something boring when he reported for international duty and fans saying they hoped he stays like this," laughed Hayk Milkon, one of Lammens' former coaches.
"This 'boringness' is just the way Senne is, he's really calm and no excesses. He focuses on what he needs to focus on and is open with the people around him. He keeps his feet on the ground."

If Lammens looks like someone who could work in an office, every workplace would love to have him in their five-a-side team. United believe they have signed a young goalkeeper with huge potential, and fans who were present at Old Trafford against Sunderland left the stadium buzzing about his debut.
The quirk is that Lammens appears to be a different person when he wears his goalkeeper kit. He made a supremely confident United debut, aggressively commanded his area and kept a clean sheet.
Milkon coached Lammens during their time together at Club Brugge. Milkon is now the youngest manager in the Belgian top-flight and Lammens plays for the biggest club in England.
"It was Senne with his headphones on. He would go into the gym to do his recovery or some extra top-ups. Or he would just go to relax by playing basketball - he loved to play basketball."

Milkon coached in different roles at Club Brugge. He was the assistant of Club NXT (their reserve team), served as their interim manager, was in charge of the Under-18s and eventually became a first-team coach.
His time at Club Brugge coincided with Lammens progressing from the academy to their first team, so he is uniquely positioned to provide insight into United's new goalkeeper signing.

Lammens joined Club Brugge's academy when he was 12. "He was a guy with huge potential," said Milkon. "As I learned from colleagues who had worked with him when he was much younger, I heard there was a moment that clicked in his head when he became super professional.
"He was one of the guys during Covid - when the players were not able to train - who was doing a lot at home, he was really going far with this to be the best in these types of areas.
"Then he continued like this when he joined the first team to train with them. He always wanted to improve. We also had something in place to look at the parameters on which goalkeepers are judged.
"You see the potential of the goalkeeper based on what they do in games; so their positioning, their decision-making and so on, and Senne was always quite high in these areas.
"The only bad luck that he had was that the first-team goalkeeper was Simon Mignolet. He's an amazing goalkeeper, so it was difficult for Senne to stay over there in the role of No.2.
"That would have also blocked his growth, so it was good for him in the end to make the step to go to Antwerp and he did a tremendous job there. It was amazing to see how fast he adapted."
Milkon continued: "I think for us at Club Brugge, it was very clear to everyone that Senne was a top goalkeeper. He would have been the perfect fit for Club Brugge to be the No.1.
"That was not possible because Mignolet was there. But the parameters that we used to judge his performances indicated he was ticking so many boxes already, and he was consistently doing it.

"There weren't ups and downs with his performances. He was consistently really high and when you compare this to the top goalkeepers, you have a benchmark to say 'Ok, what potential does this guy have?'
"He had some chances with the first team at Club Brugge and made a mistake, or maybe two, but in the end it was very clear to everyone that he was a top goalkeeper.
"It was impossible to try to extend his contract because, again, you have Mignolet, and you cannot block a guy like this. You know he has to go out, he has to play, and he will improve even more."

When asked about Lammens' strengths, he said: "I would say that his decision-making was very good. He is very calm, he sees the solutions on the pitch, he has a quick reaction time and understands the balance between risk and reward, and which decisions are the right ones to make.

"His clean passing is great, his footwork was really good, and he's just an amazing goalkeeper with the shot-stopping. He made some incredible saves back then already. He's quite a complete goalkeeper.
"But making the right decisions at a very young age, being very mature with this, was really impressive. And the fact that he is good with both feet is another big strength.
"For me, Senne is a very calm guy and has all the qualities to be a top professional. That was my impression when I first met him when he was younger and he never changed."

Lammens joined Royal Antwerp on a free transfer in the summer of 2023. He was handed his debut a few months later and served as an understudy that season, but earned first-choice status for 2024/2025.
His performances drew attention from the Belgian media. Lammens saved four penalties across a successful first full campaign and received a call-up to Belgium's senior squad in March.

Milkon said: "I was not surprised when I saw Manchester United had come calling. And to record his first clean sheet, I was really happy for him. Senne is a potential No.1 for the Red Devils - the Belgium national team.

"He got his chance, he took it, and we're all really proud of him, but we knew it would happen. I believe he has all the capabilities to become the best in the world, so I wish him all the best. I'm sure he will have a very good career in England, and Manchester United should return to the big club they used to be.
"He will have a positive impact on that, for sure, and hopefully he will be Belgium's first-choice goalkeeper soon. I believe he has the potential, the skillset and the personality to do that.
"For me, it was just having a tiny little part in having an influence on him at Brugge, but it was the most positive memories of our relationship that we had during this spell.

"I'm very proud that he is reaching these high levels and not surprised. I believe he will be successful because he is a guy who will not change his focus or start to do something different. He is calm, that's his personality and character, and he wants to succeed. He is hungry and will keep working to be his best.

"He is so calm, and you have to be patient in football. You cannot worry too much and want things too early, but finding the balance between not being impatient and, at the same time, pushing and demanding what you deserve in a good way, means everything will sort itself out."
United staff who have worked with Lammens at Carrington have echoed Milkon's sentiments. He has been described as "really mature for his age" and is said to have taken the move in his stride.

Lammens is understood to have impressed coaches during training sessions and a United source said that lots of people have been speaking positively about him. He has already relocated from the luxury hotel where he was initially staying and into a house.
It's no surprise that Lammens likes to play basketball at 6ft 3in, but he is a keen golfer, which is common ground with the likes of Tom Heaton, Luke Shaw, Mason Mount and Harry Maguire.

Matthijs de Ligt, Amad, Maguire and Shaw jogged straight to Lammens to congratulate him after full-time against Sunderland. "Are you Schmeichel in disguise?" was chanted at Lammens from the Stretford End.
It remains to be seen whether Lammens will start against Liverpool on Sunday, but it would be a surprise to see him on the bench after delivering a strong debut before the international break.
There would be nothing boring about keeping another clean sheet - this time at Anfield.
